title_full:
The Wolfgang Press

              —
              A 2nd Shape
            
              (Downwards)
label: Downwards
description:
Cult 4AD post-punk legends The Wolfgang Press make an unexpected return with a first studio album in almost three decades, and it's a doozy. Returning to the grim soundscapes and twitchy post-punk mood of their earliest, edgiest material, they sound fully invigorated and at home on Karl O'Connor's Downwards, who has been a fan since the band's earliest material in 1983.

Formed from the ashes of Rema-Rema and Mass in the early '80s, The Wolfgang Press were originally a trio of bassist... more

title_full:
EINSTURZENDE NEUBAUTEN

              —
              Rampen (APM: Alien Pop Music)
            
              (POTOMAK)
label: APM: Alien Pop Music
description:
Veteran industrial influencers Einstürzende Neubauten do alien pop music inflected with traces of folk on an intriguing addition to their swelling catalogue of some 44 years.

“They search for new forms - pursuing undiscovered sounds and unspoken words.
Since the band was founded on April 1, 1980, Einstürzende Neubauten have been shifting the parameters of mainstream and subculture to make the inaudible audible - perhaps the unheard as well. This experimental field research... more

Tristwch y Fenywod

              —
              Tristwch y Fenywod
            
              (Night School)
label: Night School
description:
An utterly addictive masterpiece of Welsh-sung queer goth folk, the debut recording by Gwretsien Ferch Lisbeth (Guttersnipe, The Ephemeron Loop), Leila Lygad (Hawthonn) and Sidni Sarffwraig (Slaylor Moon, The Courtneys) is among this decade’s most bewitching albums, bar none - unmissable for fans of Cranes, Dead Can Dance, Svitlana Nianio, Cocteau Twins' 'Head Over Heels', The Cure's 'The Top' era.

Under a handle translating to ‘The Sadness of Women’, Tristwch Y Fenywod... more

title_full:
Various Artists

              —
              Premonitions: Underground Cassette Network 1989​-​90
            
              (Infinite Expanse)
label: Infinite Expanse
description:
Superb ferric foraging on London’s Infinite Expanse, charting lesser-explored recesses of Slough’s Sound Image label with ambient industrial doings from Downwards-related Antonym and TAL’s Konrad Kraft plus cult shade dwellers M. Nomized, Jack Hurwitz, Omega Ensemble, and many names new to us, at least - RIYL Spencer Clark, Discrepant, MAAT, Enno Velthuys

“Birthed through the space provided by the Enterprise Allowance Scheme, a UK government initiative introduced in the mid-80s... more

title_full:
Felix K

            —

Civilistjävel!

              —
              Br​ö​df​ö​da
            
              (FELT)
label: FELT
description:
Civilistjävel! returns with a beautiful new double album of aqueous home listening skewed by faint vocal whirls and atmospheric dub vapours, featuring collaborations with Laila Sakini, Mayssa Jallad, Thommy Wahlström, ELDON, and Withdrawn.

‘Brödföda’ invites an audience with the esteemed Swede and his peculiar brand of atmospheric isolationism. After gently weaving in the voice of Cucina Povera on the ‘Fyra Platser’ 12”, and reimagining the kosmische dream-pop of Death &... more

title_full:
EXIT ELECTRONICS

            —
            BODY BUILDER

Zelienople

              —
              Everything Is Simple
            
              (Shelter Press)
label: Shelter Press
description:
Zelienople land on Shelter Press with a hushed swirl of vaporous vocals and hollowed-out rhythms that takes Talk Talk's 'Spirit of Eden' blueprint and tangles it with Labradford-era Chicago post-rock, 20th century minimalism and dreamy Fourth World ambience. 

Zelienople don't release much, but when they do you, can guarantee it'll be special. It's been four years since their last album, 2020's Miasmah-released 'Hold You Up, and since then the band have switched up their working... more

title_full:
Julian Cope

            —
            Friar Tuck

KMRU, Kevin Richard Martin

              —
              Disconnect
            
              (PHANTOM LIMB)
label: PHANTOM LIMB
description:
KMRU's first collaboration with Kevin Martin (aka The Bug) is a genuine surprise - shelving his mics and synthesizers, KMRU unleashes his voice, keening softly and adding chilling spoken word passages to Martin's soundsystem-baiting drones and frozen, cinematic orchestrals.

We've heard plenty of different music from KMRU over the last few years, but until now, his voice is an element he's left relatively unexplored. It was an invitation from Martin that prompted the experimentation; Martin... more

title_full:
Germ Lattice

              —
              Gipping Through the Ages
            
              (Horn Of Plenty)
label: Horn Of Plenty
description:
Dirt-caked, tape-damaged outsider jams at their filthiest, Germ Lattice's debut is a flagrant deconstruction of post-punk, unravelling screwed basslines, chants and ritualistic beats with time dilating, on-the-fly concrète processes and canny studio techniques. Properly advanced biz, bit like hearing Valerio Tricoli let loose on The Fall's master tapes.

Friends for years when they were knocking around in London, it wasn't until Joe Barton, Mickey Donnelly and Louie Rice moved to Norwich and... more
